title: How to Enjoy Turkish Coffee

steps.headline: If using coffee beans, grind them to a powder-like consistency.
steps.description: For authentic Turkish coffee, however, consider purchasing ground Turkish coffee, which is available online or at international or Middle Eastern supermarkets. Kurukahveci Mehmet Efendi is the most commonly used brand of ground Turkish coffee.

steps.headline: Pour cold water into the cezve, using a demitasse as measuring cup.
Add one heaping teaspoon of coffee per cup.
Add (optionally) one teaspoon of sugar to every two teaspoons of coffee.
steps.description: Stir until the sugar is dissolved. Turkish coffee can also be enjoyed with less sugar or even without it. If possible, ask your guests how much sugar they'd like in their coffee beforehand. Turkish coffee is often served with three levels of sweetness: plain (no sugar), medium sweetness (1/2 tsp per person), or very sweet (1 tsp per person).

steps.headline: Put the cezve on low heat.
steps.description: Watch for the froth to build.

steps.headline: Remove from heat as soon as froth starts to build.
steps.description: Pour the froth into each cup so the cups are about 1/3 to 1/2 full.

steps.headline: Repeat steps 5 to 7.
steps.description: Wait for the coffee to boil again.

steps.headline: Once it's boiling, take the cezve off heat and pour the coffee into demitasses.

text: If using coffee beans, grind them to a powder-like consistency. For authentic Turkish coffee, however, consider purchasing ground Turkish coffee, which is available online or at international or Middle Eastern supermarkets. Kurukahveci Mehmet Efendi is the most commonly used brand of ground Turkish coffee. Pour cold water into the cezve, using a demitasse as measuring cup.  Add one heaping teaspoon of coffee per cup.  Add (optionally) one teaspoon of sugar to every two teaspoons of coffee. Stir until the sugar is dissolved. Turkish coffee can also be enjoyed with less sugar or even without it. If possible, ask your guests how much sugar they'd like in their coffee beforehand. Turkish coffee is often served with three levels of sweetness: plain (no sugar), medium sweetness (1/2 tsp per person), or very sweet (1 tsp per person). Put the cezve on low heat. Watch for the froth to build. Remove from heat as soon as froth starts to build. Pour the froth into each cup so the cups are about 1/3 to 1/2 full. Repeat steps 5 to 7. Wait for the coffee to boil again. Once it's boiling, take the cezve off heat and pour the coffee into demitasses.  Enjoy!
